simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Field Suggestions Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found \"did you mean\" in error message - field suggestions are enabled"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL response discloses schema details and provides helpful field suggestions. The errors explicitly state that 'albumId' is not defined on CreatePhotoInput and suggest the correct field names 'title' and 'url' for the Photo type. This behavior enables an attacker to enumerate types and valid field names (schema discovery), which can facilitate targeted probes and further attacks. Such informative validation messages constitute information disclosure (field_suggestions). It is recommended to suppress or genericize validation messages in production (avoid returning specific field/type suggestions) or gate them behind authenticated/admin contexts.", "evidence": "Error messages returned by the API: \"Field \\\"albumId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreatePhotoInput\\\".\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"titlle\\\" on type \\\"Photo\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"urll\\\" on type \\\"Photo\\\". Did you mean \\\"url\\\"?\"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Error messages returned by the API: \"Field \\\"albumId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreatePhotoInput\\\".\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"titlle\\\" on type \\\"Photo\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"urll\\\" on type \\\"Photo\\\". Did you mean \\\"url\\\"?\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response discloses schema details and provides helpful field suggestions. The errors explicitly state that 'albumId' is not defined on CreatePhotoInput and suggest the correct field names 'title' and 'url' for the Photo type. This behavior enables an attacker to enumerate types and valid field names (schema discovery), which can facilitate targeted probes and further attacks. Such informative validation messages constitute information disclosure (field_suggestions). It is recommended to suppress or genericize validation messages in production (avoid returning specific field/type suggestions) or gate them behind authenticated/admin contexts."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "SQL Injection (SQLi) Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "SQL injection vulnerability detected - malicious SQL patterns found in response", "evidence": "Response status: 200, SQL patterns detected in response"}]

[{"detection_name": "Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "XSS injection vulnerability detected - malicious script patterns found in response", "evidence": "Response status: 200, XSS patterns detected in response data"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: xss_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns a title field containing an unescaped script tag. This is clear evidence that user-controlled input (the photo title) can contain raw HTML/JavaScript. If a client application inserts this value into a web page without proper output encoding or sanitization, the script will execute (stored/reflected XSS). Recommend treating this as untrusted input: perform server-side validation/sanitization, ensure output encoding in the rendering context (HTML-encode), and enforce a strong Content Security Policy to mitigate execution.", "evidence": "Response data: data.createPhoto.title = \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "xss_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "Response data: data.createPhoto.title = \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns a title field containing an unescaped script tag. This is clear evidence that user-controlled input (the photo title) can contain raw HTML/JavaScript. If a client application inserts this value into a web page without proper output encoding or sanitization, the script will execute (stored/reflected XSS). Recommend treating this as untrusted input: perform server-side validation/sanitization, ensure output encoding in the rendering context (HTML-encode), and enforce a strong Content Security Policy to mitigate execution."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "SSRF injection vulnerability detected - internal network access patterns found", "evidence": "Response status: 200, SSRF keywords detected in response"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: ssrf_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL mutation response (createPhoto) returns URLs that point to internal-only endpoints: 169.254.169.254 is the cloud instance metadata service (IMDS) and 127.0.0.1 is localhost. In typical image-upload/processing flows the server will fetch a supplied URL to validate or generate thumbnails. The presence of these internal addresses in the created resource strongly indicates the server performed a server-side HTTP request to attacker-controlled input that reached internal network endpoints \u2014 a classic SSRF. Accessing IMDS can disclose sensitive credentials and lead to full account compromise. Recommended actions: treat this as confirmed SSRF behavior until proven otherwise, reproduce with controlled payloads, block metadata and private IP ranges from outbound fetches, enforce an allowlist for remote hosts, validate and canonicalize URLs, and implement network egress controls and request-timeouts/port restrictions.", "evidence": "Response contains URLs pointing to internal addresses: \"url\": \"http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/iam/security-credentials/\" and \"thumbnailUrl\": \"http://127.0.0.1/status\"", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "ssrf_injection", "severity": "CRITICAL", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "Response contains URLs pointing to internal addresses: \"url\": \"http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/iam/security-credentials/\" and \"thumbnailUrl\": \"http://127.0.0.1/status\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL mutation response (createPhoto) returns URLs that point to internal-only endpoints: 169.254.169.254 is the cloud instance metadata service (IMDS) and 127.0.0.1 is localhost. In typical image-upload/processing flows the server will fetch a supplied URL to validate or generate thumbnails. The presence of these internal addresses in the created resource strongly indicates the server performed a server-side HTTP request to attacker-controlled input that reached internal network endpoints \u2014 a classic SSRF. Accessing IMDS can disclose sensitive credentials and lead to full account compromise. Recommended actions: treat this as confirmed SSRF behavior until proven otherwise, reproduce with controlled payloads, block metadata and private IP ranges from outbound fetches, enforce an allowlist for remote hosts, validate and canonicalize URLs, and implement network egress controls and request-timeouts/port restrictions."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Path Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "Path injection vulnerability detected - file system access patterns found", "evidence": "Response status: 200, Path injection patterns detected in response"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: path_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns a thumbnailUrl containing a directory traversal payload (\"../../../../../../etc/passwd\"). This is a clear indicator of path manipulation: the payload references an absolute sensitive file on UNIX systems using '../' sequences. In the context of a createPhoto operation, the server appears to accept or produce filesystem paths without proper canonicalization or sanitization, which can allow attackers to traverse directories and reference sensitive files. While the response does not contain the contents of /etc/passwd, returning such a path strongly suggests a path traversal (path injection) weakness that could be exploited to read arbitrary files or otherwise interact with the filesystem if used by backend file access routines. Recommend treating as high risk: validate and canonicalize all path inputs, reject ../ sequences, enforce a safe base directory, apply least privilege to file access, and log/monitor attempts.", "evidence": "\"thumbnailUrl\": \"../../../../../../etc/passwd\"", "confidence": 0.7, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "path_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.7, "evidence": "\"thumbnailUrl\": \"../../../../../../etc/passwd\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns a thumbnailUrl containing a directory traversal payload (\"../../../../../../etc/passwd\"). This is a clear indicator of path manipulation: the payload references an absolute sensitive file on UNIX systems using '../' sequences. In the context of a createPhoto operation, the server appears to accept or produce filesystem paths without proper canonicalization or sanitization, which can allow attackers to traverse directories and reference sensitive files. While the response does not contain the contents of /etc/passwd, returning such a path strongly suggests a path traversal (path injection) weakness that could be exploited to read arbitrary files or otherwise interact with the filesystem if used by backend file access routines. Recommend treating as high risk: validate and canonicalize all path inputs, reject ../ sequences, enforce a safe base directory, apply least privilege to file access, and log/monitor attempts."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "HTML Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "HTML injection vulnerability detected - HTML markup found in response", "evidence": "Response status: 200, HTML patterns detected in response data"}]
llm_results:
[{"detection_name": "LLM: html_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns raw HTML and a JavaScript event handler in data fields. Specifically, thumbnailUrl contains an tag with an onerror JavaScript payload (alert(document.cookie)). If a client renders these values into the DOM without proper output encoding or sanitization (for example via innerHTML), this will result in HTML injection leading to XSS and potential session theft or arbitrary script execution. The presence of the payload in the API response indicates stored/reflected injection at the application layer. Remediation: validate or sanitize HTML input server-side, and always escape or contextually encode data before inserting it into HTML; preferably render content as text or use a safe HTML sanitizer/library.", "evidence": "Response contains unescaped HTML/JS in data: title = \"
Hello
\", thumbnailUrl = \"\"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "html_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Response contains unescaped HTML/JS in data: title = \"
Hello
\", thumbnailUrl = \"\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns raw HTML and a JavaScript event handler in data fields. Specifically, thumbnailUrl contains an tag with an onerror JavaScript payload (alert(document.cookie)). If a client renders these values into the DOM without proper output encoding or sanitization (for example via innerHTML), this will result in HTML injection leading to XSS and potential session theft or arbitrary script execution. The presence of the payload in the API response indicates stored/reflected injection at the application layer. Remediation: validate or sanitize HTML input server-side, and always escape or contextually encode data before inserting it into HTML; preferably render content as text or use a safe HTML sanitizer/library."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Field Suggestions Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found \"did you mean\" in error message - field suggestions are enabled"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "safe", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL API returns validation errors that include suggested field names from the schema (e.g., suggesting 'title' and 'url' for mistyped fields). This reveals schema details and aids an attacker in enumerating valid field names. While this is an information disclosure rather than direct code injection or data leak, it lowers the effort required to probe the API and may facilitate further attacks (targeted queries, authorization probing). Recommend disabling or sanitizing suggestion messages in production error responses, returning generic validation errors, or restricting error detail to authenticated/privileged users.", "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"titlle\\\" on type \\\"Photo\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"urll\\\" on type \\\"Photo\\\". Did you mean \\\"url\\\"?\" (extensions.code = \"GRAPHQL_VALIDATION_FAILED\", HTTP 400)", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"titlle\\\" on type \\\"Photo\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"urll\\\" on type \\\"Photo\\\". Did you mean \\\"url\\\"?\" (extensions.code = \"GRAPHQL_VALIDATION_FAILED\", HTTP 400)", "explanation": "The GraphQL API returns validation errors that include suggested field names from the schema (e.g., suggesting 'title' and 'url' for mistyped fields). This reveals schema details and aids an attacker in enumerating valid field names. While this is an information disclosure rather than direct code injection or data leak, it lowers the effort required to probe the API and may facilitate further attacks (targeted queries, authorization probing). Recommend disabling or sanitizing suggestion messages in production error responses, returning generic validation errors, or restricting error detail to authenticated/privileged users."}}]
